intro: Quercus hypoleucoides, commonly known as the white oak of the highlands, is a deciduous tree native to the eastern United States. It is characterized by its broad, lobed leaves that turn a striking red or brown in the fall. The tree produces small, acorn-like fruits that are an important food source for wildlife. Its bark is thick and deeply furrowed, providing protection against pests and environmental stress. Quercus hypoleucoides is adapted to well-drained soils and full sun, making it a resilient species in forest ecosystems.
